thread.title: Umpqua Hot Springs, already closed for E. coli levels, now tests positive for bleach
thread.title_full: Umpqua Hot Springs, already closed for E. coli levels, now tests positive for bleach | OregonLive.com

author: Andrew Theen | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: Umpqua Hot Springs, already closed for E. coli levels, now tests positive for bleach
text:
The Umpqua Hot Springs, about 70 miles east of Roseburg, closed to the public due to "very high" E. coli counts two weeks ago, and now forest officials say the popular springs are suffering from another possible public safety concern: bleach.
U.S. Forest Service employees working at the Diamond Lake Ranger District about 25 miles east of the hot springs started hearing reports in the past week or so of people walking away from the popular recreation area while carrying bottles of bleach.
Subsequent water tests showed "unusually low natural bacteria counts," according to District Ranger Jimmy Tyree.
The tests also showed anomalies that confirmed a disinfectant was probably poured into the area.
"There's a lot of folks that care deeply about this area," Tyree said of the hot springs, which draws thousands of visitors in the summer months. "They're probably hoping that they can help fix it themselves," he said of the E. coli. "However in this situation there's more damage done by dumping bleach in there."
It's also a federal crime to introduce chemicals or other pollutants into natural bodies of water on federal land.
Tyree said bleach may lower E. coli, but there are lots of wildlife that use the area, and other damage that can be done "because of these harsh chemicals in this natural area."
The four to five pools at the hot springs are popular. In 2015, the district estimated 8,000 to 11,000 visitors.
Officials said they'd noticed particularly heavy use in the past year and decided to test the water. "There's not a lot of water cycling through," Tyree noted, hence the high E. coli levels last month.
The hot springs eventually flow into the North Umpqua River.
Federal officials will continue to monitor and test the water, but it's possible the hot springs will remain closed until June 2016.
According to a news release, the forest service is "working on a long-term solution" to address public safety issues.
